item.title: Azure
item.description: Set up 1.1.1.1 - Azure Log in to your Azure portal. From the Azure portal side menu, select Virtual Networks. Navigate to the virtual network associated with your virtual machine (VM). Select DNS Servers > Custom, and add two entries: 1.1.1.1 1.0.0.1 Select Save.

item.title: Gaming consoles
item.description: Set up 1.1.1.1 - Gaming consoles ​​ PS4 Go to Settings > Network > Set Up Internet Connection. Select WiFi or LAN depending on your Internet connection. Select Custom. Set IP Address Settings to Automatic. Change DHCP Host Name to Do Not Specify. Set DNS Settings to Manual. Change Primary DNS and Secondary DNS to: 1.1.1.1 1.0.0.1 If you are able to add more DNS servers, you can add the IPv6 addresses as well: 2606:4700:4700::1111 2606:4700:4700::1001 Set MTU Settings to Automatic.

item.title: Linux
item.description: Set up 1.1.1.1 - LinuxTake note of any DNS addresses you might have set up, and save them in a safe place in case you need to use them later. ​​ GNOME (Ubuntu, Fedora, Pop!_OS etc) Go to Show Applications > Settings > Network. Select the adapter you want to configure — like your Ethernet adapter or WiFi card — and select the Settings button. On the IPv4 tab > DNS section, disable the Automatic toggle.

item.title: Router
item.description: Set up 1.1.1.1 - Router Go to the IP address used to access your router’s admin console in your browser. Linksys and Asus routers typically use http://192.168.1.1 or http://router.asus.com (for ASUS). Netgear routers typically use http://192.168.1.1 or http://routerlogin.net. D-Link routers typically use http://192.168.0.1. Ubiquiti routers typically use http://unifi.ubnt.com. Enter the router credentials. For consumer routers, the default credentials for the admin console are often found under or behind the device.

item.title: Windows
item.description: Set up 1.1.1.1 - Windows ​​ Windows 10 Take note of any DNS addresses you might have set up, and save them in a safe place in case you need to use them later. Select the Start menu > Settings. On Network and Internet, select Change Adapter Options. Right-click on the Ethernet or WiFi network you are connected to and select Properties. Choose Internet Protocol Version 4. Select Properties > Use the following DNS server addresses.

item.title: Check connection to 1.1.1.1
item.description: Check connection to 1.1.1.1After setting up 1.1.1.1, you can check if you are correctly connected to Cloudflare’s resolver. Open a web browser on a configured device (smartphone or computer) or on a device connected to your configured router. Enter https://1.1.1.1/help on the browser address bar. Wait for the page to load and run its tests. The page will present you a summary of the type of connection you have to 1.
